header.title: Editorial
authors: The Editor of Australian Journal of Parapsychology

central_thesis: The editorial highlights the Australian Journal of Parapsychology's efforts to expand its reach and attract new contributors and subscribers globally, while also emphasizing the growing recognition and coming-of-age of parapsychological research in Australia, moving beyond its perception as a 'lost Continent' in the field.

structure_content.summary: The editorial describes the journal's strategic outreach to 250 members of the Parapsychological Association (PA) worldwide. This initiative involved distributing a booklet showcasing the contents of the first four volumes of AJPara and advertisements for related publications like 'A Glossary of Terms Used in Parapsychology' (2nd ed.) and 'Parapsychology in the 21st Century. Essays on the Future of Psychical Research'. The aim is to attract more subscribers and encourage scholarly submissions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Welcome to New Subscribers and Australian Parapsychology's Emergence
structure_content.summary: The editorial extends a welcome to new, especially international, subscribers, hoping they find value in the journal's content and consider it for their scholarly papers. It references a past comment by Dr. John Beloff (1977) about Australia being a 'lost Continent' for parapsychological research, then asserts that Australia, or 'Terra Australis', is now maturing in the field, indicating a significant growth in its parapsychological activities and recognition.

key_concepts.definition: The chief professional organization of parapsychologists globally, with 250 members targeted for outreach by the Australian Journal of Parapsychology.
Abbreviation for the Australian Journal of Parapsychology, the publication referenced in the editorial. Its first four volumes' contents pages were reproduced for a promotional booklet.
A historical perception of Australia in the context of parapsychological research, as expressed by Dr. John Beloff in 1977, implying a lack of significant activity or recognition in the field.

A term used in the editorial to signify Australia's current state of 'coming of age parapsychologically,' contrasting with the former 'lost Continent' perception and indicating its growing importance in the field.

practical_system.description: This text is an editorial for an academic journal focused on parapsychology. It does not describe or propose any practical system, whether magical, occult, or otherwise. Its purpose is to inform readers about journal activities, outreach, and the state of the field in Australia.

relevant_quotes.text: It may be of interest to readers that, through the good offices of our Managing Editor Robb Tilley, in collaboration with the Editor, and in a bid to attract more subscribers and more contributors to the Journal, we sent a mail-out to the 250 members of the Parapsychological Association (PA), which is the chief professional organisation of parapsychologists, with members all over the world.
We in the West tend to think of Australia as the lost Continent so far as parapsychological research is concerned but it may be that more is going on than we realize.
Australia is no longer 'the lost Continent': rather, Terra Australis is coming of age parapsychologically.

critical_analysis.relevance: This editorial is highly relevant to the field of parapsychology, particularly for understanding the efforts to promote academic journals and foster international collaboration within the discipline. It highlights the perceived growth and maturation of parapsychological research in Australia, marking a shift in its global standing. It also implicitly underscores the importance of journal outreach and engagement for scholarly fields.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes current and prospective subscribers to the Australian Journal of Parapsychology, members of the Parapsychological Association (PA), and parapsychologists or researchers interested in contributing to the journal. It also speaks to individuals monitoring the global landscape of parapsychological research, especially regarding Australia's role.
